# Drivers of Nutrient Deficiencies...[*interlocking challenges*]{style="color: blue;"}

-   Government policies
-   Cropping practices
-   Climate change
-   Diets and culture

## Government Policies...

::: incremental
-   [Maize grain marketing boards guaranteeing maize markets]{style="color: blue;"}
    - to ensure staple adequacy
-   [Promoting tobacco for the export market]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   to earn foreign currency
:::

## Cropping Practices.....

::: incremental
-   [Neglecting soil pH problems...]{style="color: blue;"}
-   yet, most soils in region have low pH, acidic
    -   [due to continuous fertilizer use,]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   without promoting liming to ameliorate the problem,
-   [Hence:]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   prevalence of low crop yields,
    -   and inadequate food production,
    -   [due to reduced fertilizer efficiency, and Al toxicity.]{style="color: blue;"}
:::

## Cropping Practices...

::: incremental
-   [No meaningful crop rotation practices by small holders...]{style="color: blue;"}
-   yet, legume-cereal rotations have boosted soil fertility for millenia
-   [The lack of rotation practices is driven by...]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   govt policies encouraging maize and tobacco production
    -   [lack of viable alternative cash crops]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   and small land holdings due to population pressure
:::

## Climate change...

::: incremental
-   [Southern Africa is prone climate change effects]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   due to its geographical location.
-   [Hence:]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   frequent droughts, heat waves, erratic rainfall
    -   [leading to frequent crop failures...hunger...poverty,]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   and, therefore, widespread nutrient deficiencies.
:::

## Diets and Culture...

::: incremental
-   [Regional diets are carbohydrate heavy]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   maize based
-   [with limited protein intake]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   animal protein, un-affordable
    -   [plant proteins, not cultural]{style="color: blue;"}
-   southern Africa consumes the least pulses in Africa
    -   [there is no active promotion for pulse consumption]{style="color: blue;"}
:::

# A Strategic Solution...[*lentils*]{style="color: blue;"}

::: incremental
-   [lentils are strategic because:]{style="color: blue;"}
-   they have multiple attributes,
-   that can address the many food system challenges.
:::

## Lentils improve human health...

::: incremental
-   [They are nutritious:]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   rich in protein,
    -   rich in complex carbohydrates,
    -   rich in minerals: K, Mg, Fe, Se, folate, Ca, P, Zn
    -   richest in fiber, good for digestion, insulin regulation
:::

## Lentils improve soil health

::: incremental
-   [lentils encourage good soil husbandry]{style="color: blue;"}
-   by encouraging farmers to ameliorate soil acidity,
    -   [because lentils are very sensitive to acidic soils]{style="color: blue;"}
:::

## Lentils are water efficient...

::: incremental
-   [lentil crops require minimal rainfall]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   about 300 - 500 mm, annually
    -   compared to maize that require about double
-   [hence, lentils adapt better to shortening of rainfall seasons by climate change]{style="color: blue;"}
:::

## Lentils reduce domestic energy consumption...

::: incremental
-   [Because they cook in 10-30 minutes]{style="color: blue;"},
    -   which saves energy,
    -   and reduces deforestation,
-   [Firewood, a primary source of domestic energy in southern Africa]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   due to low generation capacity of electricity
    -   and a large, and poor rural population
:::

## Lentils improve animal health...

::: incremental
-   [Because lentil stover is:]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   more palatable,
    -   higher in digestibility,
    -   nutrients: protein, Ca, and P,
    -   [and is better than cereal stover.]{style="color: blue;"}
:::

## Lentils and the female gender...

::: incremental
-   [Women have many roles in rural households:]{style="color: blue;"}
    - labor in the fields
    - cook, collect firewood and water,
    - also head households
-   [Because lentils cook quickly:]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   they lessen firewood collection
-   [Lentils require minimum inputs, and less complicated to grow]{style="color: blue;"}
    -  therefore, ideal for female households 
:::

## Lentils and intercropping...

::: incremental
-   [Population growth drives land fragmentation in the region]{style="color: blue;"}
    - leading to inadequate holdings for many rural families
-   [lentils can be inter-cropped with cereals]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   raising unit land productivity
-   [lentil inter-crops benefit cereals]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   because lentils fix nitrogen,
    -   which improves soil fertility,
    - and crop productivity.
:::

## Lentils, a profitable cash crop...

::: incremental
-   [Lentils have a multi-billion pound (£) international market]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   major consumers in south Asia (e.g., India)
    -   where lentils are integral to daily diets
-   [Canada, the largest producer, and exporter]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   mainly by large-scale prairie farmers
-   [India, the second largest producer]{style="color: blue;"}
    -   mainly by small-holder farmers
:::

## A Food Systems Approach...

::: incremental
-   [Focusing on production, consumption, marketing, and storage:]{style="color: blue;"}

-   Consumption:
    -   [innovating and promoting lentil dishes]{style="color: blue;"}
-   Marketing:
    -   [developing local and international markets]{style="color: blue;"}
-   Storage: [ensuring product quality]{style="color: blue;"}
:::
